xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Offers routing services to businesses in local area and wide area network environments.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This service's main purpose is to provide Windows router functionality - this is not an appropriate use of workstations in an enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Routing and Remote Access
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The computer will not be able to be configured as a Windows router between different connections.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Server (LanmanServer)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Supports file, print, and named-pipe sharing over the network for this computer. If this service is stopped, these functions will be unavailable.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In a high security environment, a secure workstation should only be a client , not a server. Sharing workstation resources for remote access increases security risk as the attack surface is notably higher.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Server
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
File, print and named-pipe sharing functions will be unavailable from this machine over the network.

Note: Many remote administration tools, such as System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM), require the Server service to be operational for remote management. In addition, many vulnerability scanners use this service to scan the file system remotely.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Simple TCP/IP Services (simptcp)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Supports the following TCP/IP services: Character Generator, Daytime, Discard, Echo, and Quote of the Day.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Simple TCP/IP Services have very little purpose in a modern enterprise environment - allowing them might increase exposure and risk for attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Simple TCP/IP Services
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The Simple TCP/IP services (Character Generator, Daytime, Discard, Echo and Quote of the Day) will not be available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SNMP Service (SNMP)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enables Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) requests to be processed by this computer.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Features that enable inbound network connections increase the attack surface. In a high security environment, management of secure workstations should be handled locally.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\SNMP Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The computer will be unable to process SNMP requests.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'SSDP Discovery (SSDPSRV)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Discovers networked devices and services that use the SSDP discovery protocol, such as UPnP devices. Also announces SSDP devices and services running on the local computer.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Universal Plug n Play (UPnP) is a real security risk - it allows automatic discovery and attachment to network devices. Note that UPnP is different than regular Plug n Play (PnP). Workstations should not be advertising their services (or automatically discovering and connecting to networked services) in a security-conscious enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\SSDP Discovery
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
SSDP-based devices will not be discovered.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Telnet (TlntSvr)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enables a remote user to log on to this computer and run programs, and supports various TCP/IP Telnet clients, including UNIX-based and Windows-based computers.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Hosting a Telnet server (especially a non-secure Telnet server) from a workstation is an increased security risk, as the attack surface of that workstation is then greatly increased.
Note: This security concern applies to any Telnet server application installed on a workstation, not just the one supplied with Windows.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Telnet
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Remote user Telnet access will not be available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'UPnP Device Host (upnphost)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows UPnP devices to be hosted on this computer.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Universal Plug n Play (UPnP) is a real security risk - it allows automatic discovery and attachment to network devices. Notes that UPnP is different than regular Plug n Play (PnP). Workstations should not be advertising their services (or automatically discovering and connecting to networked services) in a security-conscious enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\UPnP Device Host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Any hosted UPnP devices will stop functioning and no additional hosted devices can be added.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Web Management Service (WMSvc)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Web Management Service enables remote and delegated management capabilities for administrators to manage for the Web server, sites and applications present on the machine.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote web administration of IIS on a workstation is an increased security risk, as the attack surface of that workstation is then greatly increased. If proper security mitigations are not followed, the chance of successful attack increases significantly.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Web Management Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Remote web-based management of IIS will not be available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Windows Error Reporting Service (WerSvc)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows errors to be reported when programs stop working or responding and allows existing solutions to be delivered. Also allows logs to be generated for diagnostic and repair services.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If a Windows Error occurs in a secure, enterprise managed environment, the error should be reported directly to IT staff for troubleshooting and remediation. There is no benefit to the corporation to report these errors directly to Microsoft, and there is some risk of unknowingly exposing sensitive data as part of the error.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Windows Error Reporting Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this service is stopped, error reporting might not work correctly and results of diagnostic services and repairs might not be displayed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Windows Event Collector (Wecsvc)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This service manages persistent subscriptions to events from remote sources that support WS-Management protocol. This includes Windows Vista event logs, hardware and IPMI-enabled event sources. The service stores forwarded events in a local Event Log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In a high security environment, remote connections to secure workstations should be minimized, and management functions should be done locally.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Windows Event Collector
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this service is stopped or disabled event subscriptions cannot be created and forwarded events cannot be accepted.
Note: Many remote management tools and third-party security audit tools depend on this service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Media Player Network Sharing Service (WMPNetworkSvc)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Shares Windows Media Player libraries to other networked players and media devices using Universal Plug and Play.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Network sharing of media from Media Player has no place in an enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Windows Media Player Network Sharing Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Windows Media Player libraries will not be shared over the network to other devices and systems.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Windows Remote Management (WS-Management) (WinRM)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service implements the WS-Management protocol for remote management. WS-Management is a standard web services protocol used for remote software and hardware management. The WinRM service listens on the network for WS-Management requests and processes them.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Features that enable inbound network connections increase the attack surface. In a high security environment, management of secure workstations should be handled locally.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\Windows Remote Management (WS-Management)
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The ability to remotely manage the system with WinRM will be lost.
Note: Many remote administration tools, such as System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM), may require the WinRM service to be operational for remote management.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'WinHTTP Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Service (WinHttpAutoProxySvc)' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: WinHTTP implements the client HTTP stack and provides developers with a Win32 API and COM Automation component for sending HTTP requests and receiving responses. In addition, WinHTTP provides support for auto-discovering a proxy configuration via its implementation of the Web Proxy Auto-Discovery (WPAD) protocol.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled .

Note: Microsoft changed the behavior of this service starting with Windows 10 Release 1709. As of that version, this service is also required for setting a manual proxy on a workstation. If this service is forcibly disabled via GPO, then users cannot even click OK in the Local Area Network (LAN) Settings dialog box in Internet Explorer. For this reason, organizations may need to selectively grant exceptions for workstations that require setting a proxy configuration (or globally if all workstations require setting a proxy manually).

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This service is primarily needed to support Web Proxy Auto-Discovery (WPAD), which is an auto-proxy discovery mechanism that is poorly designed, as it causes an excessive amount of unnecessary DNS traffic on the network, and exposes the computer to Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) risks. If an organization depends on HTTP proxy configuration, it is recommended that other client configuration mechanisms be used instead, such as Group Policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\WinHTTP Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

WPAD will cease to function for automatic HTTP proxy routing, which may prevent Internet connectivity for workstations in organizations that currently use WPAD. In addition, on Windows 10 Release 1709 or higher, users will not be able to click OK in the Local Area Network (LAN) Settings dialog box of Internet Explorer. Microsoft also cautions that some software that uses the network stack may have a functional dependency on this service, so it is advised that you test disabling this service on a representation of user workstations and applications before disabling it across the entire organization.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'World Wide Web Publishing Service (W3SVC)' is set to 'Disabled' or 'Not Installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Provides Web connectivity and administration through the Internet Information Services Manager.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled or Not Installed .

Note #2: An organization may choose to selectively grant exceptions to web developers to allow IIS (or another web server) on their workstation, in order for them to locally test & develop web pages. However, the organization should track those machines and ensure the security controls and mitigations are kept up to date, to reduce risk of compromise.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Hosting a website from a workstation is an increased security risk, as the attack surface of that workstation is then greatly increased. If proper security mitigations are not followed, the chance of successful attack increases significantly.
Note: This security concern applies to any web server application installed on a workstation, not just IIS.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to: Disabled or ensure the service is not installed.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\System Services\World Wide Web Publishing Service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
IIS Web Services will not function.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of Windows benchmarks is consistent.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of Windows benchmarks is consistent.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of Windows benchmarks is consistent.
This section contains recommendations for configuring the Windows Firewall.
This section contains recommendations for the Domain Profile of the Windows Firewall.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Firewall state' is set to 'On (recommended)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select On (recommended) to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic. If you select Off, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security will not use any of the firewall rules or connection security rules for this profile.
The recommended state for this setting is: On (recommended) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to On (recommended) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Firewall state
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Inbound connections' is set to 'Block (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Block (default) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall allows all traffic to access the system then an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Block (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Inbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Outbound connections' is set to 'Allow (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Allow (default) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Some people believe that it is prudent to block all outbound connections except those specifically approved by the user or administrator. Microsoft disagrees with this opinion, blocking outbound connections by default will force users to deal with a large number of dialog boxes prompting them to authorize or block applications such as their web browser or instant messaging software. Additionally, blocking outbound traffic has little value because if an attacker has compromised the system they can reconfigure the firewall anyway.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Allow (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Outbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Display a notification' is set to 'No'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select this option to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
The recommended state for this setting is: No .

Note: When the Apply local firewall rules setting is configured to No , it's recommended to also configure the Display a notification setting to No . Otherwise, users will continue to receive messages that ask if they want to unblock a restricted inbound connection, but the user's response will be ignored.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Firewall notifications can be complex and may confuse the end users, who would not be able to address the alert.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to No :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Settings Customize\Display a notification
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Windows Firewall will not display a notification when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Name' is set to '%SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\domainfw.log'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\domainfw.log .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\domainfw.log :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Logging Customize\Name
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file will be stored in the specified file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: 16,384 KB or greater .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to 16,384 KB or greater :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Logging Customize\Size limit (KB)
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file size will be limited to the specified size, old events will be overwritten by newer ones when the limit is reached.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason. The log records why and when the packet was dropped. Look for entries with the word DROP in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Logging Customize\Log dropped packets
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about dropped packets will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection. The log records why and when the connection was formed. Look for entries with the word ALLOW in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile\Logging Customize\Log successful connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about successful connections will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for the Private Profile of the Windows Firewall.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Firewall state' is set to 'On (recommended)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select On (recommended) to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic. If you select Off, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security will not use any of the firewall rules or connection security rules for this profile.
The recommended state for this setting is: On (recommended) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to On (recommended) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Firewall state
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Inbound connections' is set to 'Block (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Block (default) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall allows all traffic to access the system then an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Block (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Inbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Outbound connections' is set to 'Allow (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Allow (default) .

Note: If you set Outbound connections to Block and then deploy the firewall policy by using a GPO, computers that receive the GPO settings cannot receive subsequent Group Policy updates unless you create and deploy an outbound rule that enables Group Policy to work. Predefined rules for Core Networking include outbound rules that enable Group Policy to work. Ensure that these outbound rules are active, and thoroughly test firewall profiles before deploying.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Some people believe that it is prudent to block all outbound connections except those specifically approved by the user or administrator. Microsoft disagrees with this opinion, blocking outbound connections by default will force users to deal with a large number of dialog boxes prompting them to authorize or block applications such as their web browser or instant messaging software. Additionally, blocking outbound traffic has little value because if an attacker has compromised the system they can reconfigure the firewall anyway.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Allow (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Outbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Settings: Display a notification' is set to 'No'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select this option to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
The recommended state for this setting is: No .

Note: When the Apply local firewall rules setting is configured to No , it's recommended to also configure the Display a notification setting to No . Otherwise, users will continue to receive messages that ask if they want to unblock a restricted inbound connection, but the user's response will be ignored.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Firewall notifications can be complex and may confuse the end users, who would not be able to address the alert.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to No :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Settings Customize\Display a notification
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Windows Firewall will not display a notification when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Name' is set to '%SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\privatefw.log'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\privatefw.log .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\privatefw.log :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Logging Customize\Name
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file will be stored in the specified file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: 16,384 KB or greater .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to 16,384 KB or greater :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Logging Customize\Size limit (KB)
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file size will be limited to the specified size, old events will be overwritten by newer ones when the limit is reached.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason. The log records why and when the packet was dropped. Look for entries with the word DROP in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Logging Customize\Log dropped packets
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about dropped packets will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection. The log records why and when the connection was formed. Look for entries with the word ALLOW in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Private Profile\Logging Customize\Log successful connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about successful connections will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for the Public Profile of the Windows Firewall.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Firewall state' is set to 'On (recommended)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select On (recommended) to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic. If you select Off, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security will not use any of the firewall rules or connection security rules for this profile.
The recommended state for this setting is: On (recommended) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to On (recommended):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Firewall state
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Inbound connections' is set to 'Block (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Block (default) .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the firewall allows all traffic to access the system then an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Block (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Inbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Outbound connections' is set to 'Allow (default)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
The recommended state for this setting is: Allow (default) .

Note: If you set Outbound connections to Block and then deploy the firewall policy by using a GPO, computers that receive the GPO settings cannot receive subsequent Group Policy updates unless you create and deploy an outbound rule that enables Group Policy to work. Predefined rules for Core Networking include outbound rules that enable Group Policy to work. Ensure that these outbound rules are active, and thoroughly test firewall profiles before deploying.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Some people believe that it is prudent to block all outbound connections except those specifically approved by the user or administrator. Microsoft disagrees with this opinion, blocking outbound connections by default will force users to deal with a large number of dialog boxes prompting them to authorize or block applications such as their web browser or instant messaging software. Additionally, blocking outbound traffic has little value because if an attacker has compromised the system they can reconfigure the firewall anyway.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Allow (default) :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Outbound connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Settings: Display a notification' is set to 'No'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Select this option to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
The recommended state for this setting is: No .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Some organizations may prefer to avoid alarming users when firewall rules block certain types of network activity. However, notifications can be helpful when troubleshooting network issues involving the firewall.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to 'No':
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Settings Customize\Display a notification
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Windows Firewall will not display a notification when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Settings: Apply local firewall rules' is set to 'No'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create local firewall rules that apply together with firewall rules configured by Group Policy.
The recommended state for this setting is: No .

Note: When the Apply local firewall rules setting is configured to No , it's recommended to also configure the Display a notification setting to No . Otherwise, users will continue to receive messages that ask if they want to unblock a restricted inbound connection, but the user's response will be ignored.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: When in the Public profile, there should be no special local firewall exceptions per computer. These settings should be managed by a centralized policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to No :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Settings Customize\Apply local firewall rules
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Administrators can still create firewall rules, but the rules will not be applied.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Settings: Apply local connection security rules' is set to 'No'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create connection security rules that apply together with connection security rules configured by Group Policy.
The recommended state for this setting is: No .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users with administrative privileges might create firewall rules that expose the system to remote attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to No :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Settings Customize\Apply local connection security rules
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Administrators can still create local connection security rules, but the rules will not be applied.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Name' is set to '%SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\publicfw.log'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\publicfw.log .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to %SystemRoot%\System32\logfiles\firewall\publicfw.log :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Logging Customize\Name
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file will be stored in the specified file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
The recommended state for this setting is: 16,384 KB or greater .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to 16,384 KB or greater :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Logging Customize\Size limit (KB)
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The log file size will be limited to the specified size, old events will be overwritten by newer ones when the limit is reached.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason. The log records why and when the packet was dropped. Look for entries with the word DROP in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Logging Customize\Log dropped packets
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about dropped packets will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to 'Yes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection. The log records why and when the connection was formed. Look for entries with the word ALLOW in the action column of the log.
The recommended state for this setting is: Yes .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If events are not recorded it may be difficult or impossible to determine the root cause of system problems or the unauthorized activities of malicious users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Yes .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Public Profile\Logging Customize\Log successful connections
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Information about successful connections will be recorded in the firewall log file.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Network Access Protection NAP Client Configuration

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of Windows benchmarks is consistent.

This section contains recommendations for configuring the Windows audit facilities.
This section contains recommendations for configuring the Account Logon audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Credential Validation' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports the results of validation tests on credentials submitted for a user account logon request. These events occur on the computer that is authoritative for the credentials. For domain accounts, the Domain Controller is authoritative, whereas for local accounts, the local computer is authoritative. In domain environments, most of the Account Logon events occur in the Security log of the Domain Controllers that are authoritative for the domain accounts. However, these events can occur on other computers in the organization when local accounts are used to log on. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4774: An account was mapped for logon.
4775: An account could not be mapped for logon.
4776: The Domain Controller attempted to validate the credentials for an account.
4777: The Domain Controller failed to validate the credentials for an account.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Account Logon\Audit Credential Validation
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for configuring the Account Management audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Application Group Management' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting allows you to audit events generated by changes to application groups such as the following:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Application group is created, changed, or deleted.
Member is added or removed from an application group.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Application groups are utilized by Windows Authorization Manager, which is a flexible framework created by Microsoft for integrating role-based access control (RBAC) into applications. More information on Windows Authorization Manager is available at MSDN - Windows Authorization Manager .
The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing events in this category may be useful when investigating an incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Account Management\Audit Application Group Management
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Security Group Management' is set to include 'Success'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports each event of security group management, such as when a security group is created, changed, or deleted or when a member is added to or removed from a security group. If you enable this Audit policy setting, administrators can track events to detect malicious, accidental, and authorized creation of security group accounts. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4727: A security-enabled global group was created.
4728: A member was added to a security-enabled global group.
4729: A member was removed from a security-enabled global group.
4730: A security-enabled global group was deleted.
4731: A security-enabled local group was created.
4732: A member was added to a security-enabled local group.
4733: A member was removed from a security-enabled local group.
4734: A security-enabled local group was deleted.
4735: A security-enabled local group was changed.
4737: A security-enabled global group was changed.
4754: A security-enabled universal group was created.
4755: A security-enabled universal group was changed.
4756: A member was added to a security-enabled universal group.
4757: A member was removed from a security-enabled universal group.
4758: A security-enabled universal group was deleted.
4764: A group's type was changed.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Success .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Success:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Account Management\Audit Security Group Management
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit User Account Management' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports each event of user account management, such as when a user account is created, changed, or deleted; a user account is renamed, disabled, or enabled; or a password is set or changed. If you enable this Audit policy setting, administrators can track events to detect malicious, accidental, and authorized creation of user accounts. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4720: A user account was created.
4722: A user account was enabled.
4723: An attempt was made to change an account's password.
4724: An attempt was made to reset an account's password.
4725: A user account was disabled.
4726: A user account was deleted.
4738: A user account was changed.
4740: A user account was locked out.
4765: SID History was added to an account.
4766: An attempt to add SID History to an account failed.
4767: A user account was unlocked.
4780: The ACL was set on accounts which are members of administrators groups.
4781: The name of an account was changed:
4794: An attempt was made to set the Directory Services Restore Mode.
5376: Credential Manager credentials were backed up.
5377: Credential Manager credentials were restored from a backup.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Account Management\Audit User Account Management
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for configuring the Detailed Tracking audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Process Creation' is set to include 'Success'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports the creation of a process and the name of the program or user that created it. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4688: A new process has been created.
4696: A primary token was assigned to process.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Refer to Microsoft Knowledge Base article 947226: Description of security events in Windows Vista and in Windows Server 2008 for the most recent information about this setting.
The recommended state for this setting is to include: Success .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Success :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Detailed Tracking\Audit Process Creation
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of Windows benchmarks is consistent.
This section contains recommendations for configuring the Logon/Logoff audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Account Lockout' is set to include 'Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports when a user's account is locked out as a result of too many failed logon attempts. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4625: An account failed to log on.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Logon/Logoff\Audit Account Lockout
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Logoff' is set to include 'Success'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports when a user logs off from the system. These events occur on the accessed computer. For interactive logons, the generation of these events occurs on the computer that is logged on to. If a network logon takes place to access a share, these events generate on the computer that hosts the accessed resource. If you configure this setting to No auditing, it is difficult or impossible to determine which user has accessed or attempted to access organization computers. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4634: An account was logged off.
4647: User initiated logoff.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Success .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Success :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Logon/Logoff\Audit Logoff
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Logon' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports when a user attempts to log on to the system. These events occur on the accessed computer. For interactive logons, the generation of these events occurs on the computer that is logged on to. If a network logon takes place to access a share, these events generate on the computer that hosts the accessed resource. If you configure this setting to No auditing, it is difficult or impossible to determine which user has accessed or attempted to access organization computers. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4624: An account was successfully logged on.
4625: An account failed to log on.
4648: A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
4675: SIDs were filtered.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Logon/Logoff\Audit Logon
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Other Logon/Logoff Events' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports other logon/logoff-related events, such as Remote Desktop Services session disconnects and reconnects, using RunAs to run processes under a different account, and locking and unlocking a workstation. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4649: A replay attack was detected.
4778: A session was reconnected to a Window Station.
4779: A session was disconnected from a Window Station.
4800: The workstation was locked.
4801: The workstation was unlocked.
4802: The screen saver was invoked.
4803: The screen saver was dismissed.
5378: The requested credentials delegation was disallowed by policy.
5632: A request was made to authenticate to a wireless network.
5633: A request was made to authenticate to a wired network.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Logon/Logoff\Audit Other Logon/Logoff Events
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Special Logon' is set to include 'Success'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports when a special logon is used. A special logon is a logon that has administrator-equivalent privileges and can be used to elevate a process to a higher level. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4964 : Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Success .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Success :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Logon/Logoff\Audit Special Logon
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for configuring the Object Access audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Detailed File Share' is set to include 'Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory allows you to audit attempts to access files and folders on a shared folder. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 5145: network share object was checked to see whether client can be granted desired access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Failure

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing the Failures will log which unauthorized users attempted (and failed) to get access to a file or folder on a network share on this computer, which could possibly be an indication of malicious intent.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Object Access\Audit Detailed File Share
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit File Share' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting allows you to audit attempts to access a shared folder.
The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .
Note: There are no system access control lists (SACLs) for shared folders. If this policy setting is enabled, access to all shared folders on the system is audited.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In an enterprise managed environment, workstations should have limited file sharing activity, as file servers would normally handle the overall burden of file sharing activities. Any unusual file sharing activity on workstations may therefore be useful in an investigation of potentially malicious activity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Object Access\Audit File Share
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Other Object Access Events' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting allows you to audit events generated by the management of task scheduler jobs or COM+ objects.
For scheduler jobs, the following are audited:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Job created.
Job deleted.
Job enabled.
Job disabled.
Job updated.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: For COM+ objects, the following are audited:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Catalog object added.
Catalog object updated.
Catalog object deleted.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The unexpected creation of scheduled tasks and COM+ objects could potentially be an indication of malicious activity. Since these types of actions are generally low volume, it may be useful to capture them in the audit logs for use during an investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Object Access\Audit Other Object Access Events
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Removable Storage' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting allows you to audit user attempts to access file system objects on a removable storage device. A security audit event is generated only for all objects for all types of access requested. If you configure this policy setting, an audit event is generated each time an account accesses a file system object on a removable storage. Success audits record successful attempts and Failure audits record unsuccessful attempts. If you do not configure this policy setting, no audit event is generated when an account accesses a file system object on a removable storage.
The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .
Note: A Windows 8.0, Server 2012 (non-R2) or newer OS is required to access and set this value in Group Policy.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing removable storage may be useful when investigating an incident. For example, if an individual is suspected of copying sensitive information onto a USB drive.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Object Access\Audit Removable Storage
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected. Companies that operate in certain regulated industries may have legal obligations to log certain events or activities.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit MPSSVC Rule-Level Policy Change' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory determines whether the operating system generates audit events when changes are made to policy rules for the Microsoft Protection Service (MPSSVC.exe). Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: 4944: The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.
4945: A rule was listed when the Windows Firewall started.
4946: A change has been made to Windows Firewall exception list. A rule was added.
4947: A change has been made to Windows Firewall exception list. A rule was modified.
4948: A change has been made to Windows Firewall exception list. A rule was deleted.
4949: Windows Firewall settings were restored to the default values.
4950: A Windows Firewall setting has changed.
4951: A rule has been ignored because its major version number was not recognized by Windows Firewall.
4952: Parts of a rule have been ignored because its minor version number was not recognized by Windows Firewall. The other parts of the rule will be enforced.
4953: A rule has been ignored by Windows Firewall because it could not parse the rule.
4954: Windows Firewall Group Policy settings have changed. The new settings have been applied.
4956: Windows Firewall has changed the active profile.
4957: Windows Firewall did not apply the following rule.
4958: Windows Firewall did not apply the following rule because the rule referred to items not configured on this computer.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is : Success and Failure

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Changes to firewall rules are important for understanding the security state of the computer and how well it is protected against network attacks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Policy Change\Audit MPSSVC Rule-Level Policy Change

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Other Policy Change Events' is set to include 'Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory contains events about EFS Data Recovery Agent policy changes, changes in Windows Filtering Platform filter, status on Security policy settings updates for local Group Policy settings, Central Access Policy changes, and detailed troubleshooting events for Cryptographic Next Generation (CNG) operations.

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: 5063: A cryptographic provider operation was attempted.
5064: A cryptographic context operation was attempted.
5065: A cryptographic context modification was attempted.
5066: A cryptographic function operation was attempted.
5067: A cryptographic function modification was attempted.
5068: A cryptographic function provider operation was attempted.
5069: A cryptographic function property operation was attempted.
5070: A cryptographic function property modification was attempted.
6145: One or more errors occurred while processing security policy in the group policy objects.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is to include: Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting can help detect errors in applied Security settings which came from Group Policy, and failure events related to Cryptographic Next Generation (CNG) functions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to include Failure :

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for configuring the Privilege Use audit policy.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Audit Sensitive Privilege Use' is set to 'Success and Failure'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This subcategory reports when a user account or service uses a sensitive privilege. A sensitive privilege includes the following user rights:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Act as part of the operating system
Back up files and directories
Create a token object
Debug programs
Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation
Generate security audits
Impersonate a client after authentication
Load and unload device drivers
Manage auditing and security log
Modify firmware environment values
Replace a process-level token
Restore files and directories
Take ownership of files or other objects

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Auditing this subcategory will create a high volume of events. Events for this subcategory include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: 4672: Special privileges assigned to new logon.
4673: A privileged service was called.
4674: An operation was attempted on a privileged object.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Success and Failure .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Auditing these events may be useful when investigating a security incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Success and Failure :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Advanced Audit Policy Configuration\Audit Policies\Privilege Use\Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If no audit settings are configured, or if audit settings are too lax on the computers in your organization, security incidents might not be detected or not enough evidence will be available for network forensic analysis after security incidents occur. However, if audit settings are too severe, critically important entries in the Security log may be obscured by all of the meaningless entries and computer performance and the available amount of data storage may be seriously affected.
